Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that a clear precedent was established in 1970 and 1971 where his Department agreed to pay teachers, who had already retired, the benefit in their pensions of allowances which they never held during their own service.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 339 and 340 together.

The position is that the PCW agreement provides that the long service allowance is payable in the pay of eligible teachers who are in service on or after 1 August 1996. Since it is an allowance, rather than an increase in incremental salary, it is not payable in the pensions of teachers who retired prior to that date.

It has been contended that the long service allowance should be regarded as an increment in salary. It has also been contended, and the Deputy has referred to this, that there is a precedent for paying the allowance to teachers who retired prior to 1 August 1996 on the grounds that, in 1971, retired teachers received the benefits of post of responsibility allowances which they did not hold during service.

The position regarding the contention that the long service allowance should be regarded as an increment is that, under the restructuring pay deals, this payment was specifically agreed as an allowance. Because allowances may be pensionable or otherwise, the agreement specifically provides that “in the case of teachers retiring whilst in receipt of the allowance, the allowance would be reckonable towards superannuation entitlements subject to the normal averaging arrangements”.

The position regarding the precedent cited in the case of post of responsibility allowances is that these allowances were introduced, in the early 1970s, with retrospective effect. As in the case of the long service allowance, however, teachers who had retired prior to the agreed effective date of establishment of the post of responsibility allowances did not receive the benefit of those allowances. Specifically, no teacher who retired prior to 1 July 1968, the earliest agreed effective date, received the benefit of the allowance.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the criteria being used to select schools for home school community liaison teachers; if he has received an application from Chanel College, Coolock; and if he is in a position to accede to its request.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The home-school-community liaison scheme was introduced to schools that were designated as serving areas of disadvantage. As part of the recently announced £57 million two year funding initiative to tackle educational disadvantage, I indicated that every disadvantaged school will have a home-school-community liaison service available to it from September next. This includes Chanel College which has previously applied to be included in the scheme.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the four designated areas in which the integrated services project is being developed; the structure in place in each; the additional general and specific education budgets put at the discretion of the steering committee; the evaluation criteria being used to assess the success of the project; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The four designated integrated service project areas are: Dublin North-East inner city, Dublin canal communities – St Teresas Gardens, St Micheals Estate, Dolphin House, Fatima Mansions – Jobstown, County Dublin and Togher, Cork.

A national co-ordinator has been appointed who is based in ADM in addition to four development and monitoring officers. I have assigned Department officials to each of designated areas who will work on an implementation team representative of all Government and statutory agencies in consultation with the local communities and the development and monitoring officer. An induction seminar was held yesterday 24 February to brief all Government and state agency personnel assigned to work on this initiative.

The initiative is intended to address a hierarchy of needs including housing and environment, social order, community development, health, childcare, education, recreation, youth initiatives, training and employment. In my view, co-ordination of all state services and agencies in addressing needs is the crucial first step in optimising the benefits of services to families and individuals in these communities and to break the traditional intergenerational cycle of disadvantage. The way in which resources are deployed is as important as the level of resources available to State agencies. Research has shown that those most at risk of not benefiting from the system are the children of the unemployed or the children of early school leavers. Educational achievement therefore both initial and second chance, is a key issue to be addressed within the overall strategy. Until the implementation team is fully operational on the ground it is not possible to predict the level of additional resources, if any, which will be required in the designated areas. I am fully committed to the concept of integrated services initiatives and I assure the Deputy that the issue of resources will be addressed as appropriate.

Ongoing monitoring of the initiative will be undertaken by the development and monitoring officer at local level in conjunction with the implementation team for each area. It will probably be the end of this year or early next year before the interdepartmental committee on local development will be in a position to consider lessons from the first phase of the project.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if he will introduce a grant for those doing a degree by night who are part of community development activities and are enhancing their ability to serve their community.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: In general, under the terms of the third level student support schemes, means tested maintenance grants are made available to eligible students who are pursuing full time third level courses of at least two years duration at undergraduate level.

In its report the steering committee on the future development of higher education referred to the profile of part-time students and noted that almost 90 per cent were in employment. In this context I would point out that tax relief is available at the standard rate, under section 15 of the Finance Act, 1996, for tuition fees paid by eligible students who are attending approved part-time third level courses.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the progress in the pilot languages programme in primary schools to date giving the number of teachers who have participated in in-service training; the number of schools, if any, which have dropped out since first selected; the number of hours of foreign language teaching being provided in the schools participating; the number of children participating in language classes; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: To date, information sessions have been given by the project leaders to participating schools at 24 venues nationwide. A total of 352 project teachers have also participated in 33 intensive inservice days organised by the project leaders. Some 113 evaluation forms have been returned from the participants in the inservice days. Ninety three declared the sessions “very helpful” and 20 said they were “helpful”.

The number of participating schools in September 1998, was 271. Seven schools have dropped out since the start of the project. There are now 266 participating schools. This figure includes two schools that have recently joined for Italian.

A total of 1.5 hours' tuition is allowed for each individual 5th and 6th class participating in the project. Some of this time can be spent on teaching a small part of a largely skills-based area of the curriculum, for example, Art or P.E., through the target language.
The number of children participating in language classes is as follows: French: 9,644; German: 4,456; Spanish: 3,586; Italian: 1,243.
